events.originalText: President Olusegun Obasanjo took office as Nigeria's first elected and civilian head of state after 16 years of military dictatorship.
events.subtitle: Olusegun Obasanjo
events.headline: President Olusegun Obasanjo inaugurated as Nigeria's first civilian head of state

events.originalText: Diane Leather became the first woman to run a mile in less than five minutes.
events.subtitle: Diane Leather
events.headline: Diane Leather breaks record as first woman to run mile in under five minutes

events.originalText: The mountaineers Edmund Hillary and Tenzing Norgay (both pictured) became the first people to reach the summit of Mount Everest.
events.subtitle: Edmund Hillary
events.headline: Hillary and Norgay conquer Mount Everest summit

events.originalText: Bing Crosby recorded his version of the song "White Christmas", which went on to become the best-selling single worldwide, with more than 50 million copies sold.
events.subtitle: Bing Crosby
events.headline: Bing Crosby's 'White Christmas' becomes best-selling single worldwide

events.originalText: A strike by copper miners in Northern Rhodesia ended after six workers were shot and killed by police.
events.subtitle: 1935 Copperbelt strike
events.headline: Copper miners strike ends after police shooting in Northern Rhodesia

events.originalText: World War I: Armenian forces defeated Ottoman troops at the Battle of Sardarabad, halting the Turkish advance and preventing further destruction of the Armenian nation.
events.subtitle: World War I
events.headline: Armenian forces triumph over Ottoman troops at Battle of Sardarabad

events.originalText: During the premiere of the ballet The Rite of Spring by Igor Stravinsky (pictured) at the Théâtre des Champs-Élysées in Paris, the avant-garde nature of the music and choreography caused a near-riot in the audience.
events.subtitle: The Rite of Spring
events.headline: Riot erupts at premiere of Stravinsky's 'The Rite of Spring' in Paris

events.originalText: English dramatist W. S. Gilbert of the songwriting duo Gilbert and Sullivan died while saving a young woman from drowning in his lake.
events.subtitle: W. S. Gilbert
events.headline: W. S. Gilbert dies saving woman from drowning in lake

events.originalText: N'Djamena, now the capital of Chad, was founded as Fort-Lamy by French commander Émile Gentil.
events.subtitle: N'Djamena
events.headline: Fort-Lamy founded by French commander Émile Gentil, now N'Djamena

events.originalText: Swedish operatic soprano Jenny Lind concluded a successful concert tour of the United States under the management of showman P. T. Barnum.
events.subtitle: Soprano
events.headline: Jenny Lind concludes successful US concert tour managed by P. T. Barnum

events.originalText: The Great Sejm of the Polish–Lithuanian Commonwealth was disbanded following the Russian invasion of Poland.
events.subtitle: Great Sejm
events.headline: Great Sejm disbanded after Russian invasion of Poland

events.originalText: With the fall of Constantinople, the Byzantine Empire fell to the Ottomans.
events.subtitle: Fall of Constantinople
events.headline: Byzantine Empire falls to Ottomans with fall of Constantinople

events.originalText: A squadron of the Venetian navy captured many Ottoman ships at the Battle of Gallipoli, confirming Venetian naval superiority in the Aegean Sea for the next few decades.
events.subtitle: Venetian navy
events.headline: Venetian navy triumphs over Ottomans at Battle of Gallipoli

events.originalText: Mongol–Jin War: The Mongols entered and began looting Kaifeng, the capital of the Jin dynasty of China, after a 13-month siege.
events.subtitle: Mongol conquest of the Jin dynasty
events.headline: Mongols loot Kaifeng after 13-month siege

events.originalText: Wars of the Guelphs and Ghibellines: Troops of the Lombard League defeated forces of the Holy Roman Empire near Legnano in present-day Italy.
events.subtitle: Guelphs and Ghibellines
events.headline: Lombard League defeats Holy Roman Empire forces near Legnano
